messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> I see. But what dialects make this distinction?

Forgive me for not remembering: a quick googling didn't turn it up.
In any case, the point's the same.

> Are we talking about one exception or a rule?

A rule.

> In this case the user can either do what you
> proscribe, or the user can write in a standard dialect.

True, but I understood the idea of QS to be writing, insofar as possible,
in one's own dialect. Note that this is not a case like writing "meet"
and "meat" identically, since after all they are pronounced the same in
(almost) all dialects; here we have two words pronounced differently but
(in this dialect) written the same, something QS is supposed to avoid.

> Also, you have not described what you mean by phonemical opposition.

You're right: I danced around the definition without making it.

A phonemic opposition between two sounds exists in a given language when
there are two words of the language, one of which pronounced with one
sound and the other with the other, with no other differences between
them. The two words are called a "minimal pair".

Thus the sounds written "p" in "spin" and "pin" don't constitute a
phonemic opposition in English: the first sound is used only after
"s", the other in all other cases, so there can be no minimal pairs.
However, "pin" and "bin" do constitute a minimal pair, and so there
is a phonemic opposition between the "p" and "b" sounds in English.
In the Hindi language, there are minimal pairs for all three sounds,
and consequently three separate phonemes.

> But that system is wholly inadequate for reasons I have already pointed
> out, namely it causes confusion in both beginners and experienced users.
> When does one write #34 and when does one write #33? Right now it
> stands that I can mix up #33 and #34 however I want, since I don't hear
> a difference. Other users can simply mix up #32, #33, and #34 how they
> want. How are we to actually read such a text when written in this way?

(In my case, #32 Ah and #34 Ox are the same but #33 Awe is different.)

In the same way that we read either Pea-At-Thaw or Pea-Ah-Thaw as
"path", although some pronounce it one way and some the other.

> And as I pointed out in another email, how am I supposed to represent
> dialect, say, in a short story if the vowels have no distinct meaning?

/me shrugs.

> If we don't actually distinguish sounds, then TO actually is superior
> for expressing dialect, because it has a standard spelling, and when I
> vary from that spelling (by writting "Wundaful" for "wonderful")

Well, that happens to work, but if you are trying to represent a dialect
that uses different vowels in "north" and "force", as Boston dialect
also does (as well as Scottish and Irish varieties), then neither
Traditional nor QS will help you much, as the distinction is not
consistently represented in either.

> But if we say that #34 means whatever it does to the local user,
> then there is no way I can write say a Boston dialect or a New York
> dialect. They would all appear identical.

Up to a point. The "path" example above shows how distinctions in
individual words can be represented.

--
